newsitem.title: USA: Beaufort Sea oil lease sale draws $14.4 million.
newsitem.headline: Beaufort Sea oil lease sale draws $14.4 million.

text.p: Alaska's first outercontinental shelf oil and gas lease sale in five years drew a total $14.4 million in high bids, according to preliminary figures released by the U.S. Minerals Management Service (MMS) Wednesday.
Bids were opened Wednesday morning for Lease Sale 144, which had offered 7.3 million offshore acres in Arctic Alaska's Beaufort Sea.

The largest bid came from British Petroleum unit BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc., which offered $10.6 million for a single segment near the existing Tern unit north of Prudhoe Bay. BP also won several other tracts in the area.

Other bidders were the Arco Alaska Inc. unit of Los Angeles-based Atlantic Richfield Co., Anadarko Petroluem Corp., headquartered in Houston, San Fransisco-based Chevron Corp. and Petrofina Delaware, a unit of Belguim's Petrofina SA.
Arco, in partnership with Anadarko, won tracts north of the federally owned National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska and about 120 miles east of Prudhoe Bay.
Bidding alone, Arco won tracts near the Colville River Delta and in Camden Bay, areas where the company has already conducted exploration.
BP and Petrofina, bidding separately, won tracts directly north of Prudhoe Bay. Petrofina's bids were for tracts near the existing Sandpiper unit on the North Slope.
Chevron won tracts west of Prudhoe Bay and north of the Colville Delta.
